column10: This is an amazing casual game. I have to say I was not having much fun until after getting a decent number of quality sprinklers, but the game improves rapidly after you are no longer doing farm chores for your full day. I am not even close to finishing, but this is a great game to help me relax.

I keep coming back to this game year after year. I first played this type of game on my Super Nintendo under the name 'Harvest Moon' and have loved this style ever since. My mind is blown that this game continues to receive free, massive updates that add so much value and transform the game. In the world we live in, this is more than a breath of fresh air. Thank you for creating this game and continuing to pour your love and heart into it. It has brought so much joy to so so many people. You are incredible and I hope all the best things in life happen to you!

Honestly my time In and out of Stardew Valley has been a blast, had many hours logged into it over the years since its release, I dont know what could be said about the game that hasnt already been praised about it. 
That being said its personally helped me through some low, and Dark times in my life, Including the current dark patch Ive had to weave around this year in the last 6 months Between my ADHD and Chronic Depression.
The planning that has to go into the "End Game" between Buffs, and Food, Gear and many other things, has been a welcome and much needed distraction. I almost forgot how fun the tedium of planning out the next few potential days can be. Every item has a use, and when the items use runs out, theres more than likely another use to be found for it. Like when you run out of coal for smelting. Theres more than one way to get that item than just to find it while mining in the caves for other resources and Minerals.

Enough prattling on, on my end I guess all I have to say is Thanks @ConcernedApe for making this spiritual successor (in a way) to the old school "Harvest Moons" from way back in the day. Your work has had an impactful result on the lives of so many people. 
I hope the development of your next project goes smoothly and has an equally profound effect on the world upon its release.

Of course I recommend this game. Like what's there not to say that's good about Stardew? There's at least one thing that every kind of player may like to do, whether it be relaxing while farming, battling it out to the death in the mines, or peacefully fishing. The community couldn't be better as well. Not only are the people, artists, mod creators so very nice, but the game creator, concerned ape, is literally one of the best people that I've ever seen. For instance, he uses poles on social media to choose what new marriage candidates should be in the game, and not only does he allow modding, but he encourages it. In fact, in the time that I'm writing this, he's working on a way for it to be easier on modders to create and easier for users to download. This game is so equal, like there's gay marriage, relationships among NPC's whether it be good or bad, you can even have a friend in game and marry them if you like. Whether you're a first person shooter kind of person or a Hollow Knight playing god, you'll definitely love this game. (This game is like neither of those, just saying you'll most likely love it regardless of what you normally play.) If you don't like the game, try out some mods and see if you'd like any of those, then if you don't like those then you obviously have the choice of refunding. Just have fun with it though, don't stress about anything and just relax. If you do get into the game, just know that if you're stuck there's a wiki, and if you play a lot then definitely look out for the nice little secrets in the game.

This is literally the best game in the history of ever. I've never seen such a well thought out game in my life. My only regret is that I took so long to play it. CA put so much love and effort into this project, and along with it has grown the most amazing fan base I have ever seen. The community itself is filled with kindness and respect, really nothing but pure love for a well deserved game. For any level of gamer you might be, I can't recommend this game enough. You can stick to vanilla Stardew, or explore countless mods many talented creators have put out for free. It's an endless adventure full of fun, romance, diverse friendships, many thoughtful challenges, and beautiful scenery. Stardew Valley is much more than just a farming sim, and I can't imagine any gaming topping this for me anytime soon. 

Much Love to Eric Barone and the SDV community!

For the great price of $10 (on sale), I am absolutely amazed on how much fun I had with this game. The amazing music and ambient sounds, meeting the towns people, discovering secrets of the town and people, forming connections, feeling a part of the community, and progressing to becoming a millionaire.  Sometimes, I pause the game on rainy days and just listen to the sound of it. Might walk around and talk to the townsfolk, rearrange some of my farm, clear out some trees, and just chill, enjoying the pleasantness of rain and progressing. And other times, I get ready for battle and go the to skull cavern and progress to the bottom or farm for ore. This game is very comforting and enjoyable. And its even more amazing playing with friends!

Stardew Valley is a heartwarming farming simulation that captivates players with its charming pixel art, relaxing gameplay, and endearing characters. The peaceful life in Pelican Town, filled with seasonal activities and meaningful interactions, creates a delightful escape. The depth of the game, from crop management to mining adventures and building relationships, ensures there's always something to do. With its soothing soundtrack and a strong sense of progression, Stardew Valley is not just a game; it's a therapeutic journey that leaves you with a sense of accomplishment and joy after each harvest.

Stardew Valley has a refreshing take on farming than most farm sim games. For starters, most farm sim allows you to plant anything any time. Stardew Valley takes it further by having selected crops to plant depending on their season. And the best part about it - the crops realistically match the season where they grow in real life. 

Another thing that makes this game better than other farm simulation games is the fact that challenges your personal ethics. Whether you want to support a local business or a big corporation, it is up to you which one to support depending on how you analyze each business. 

And it is not just a cozy game where the low-key gamers can relax. Features like the mines put an exciting twist to this game that would challenge even the hardcore gamers. 

Perhaps what gives the game its unique spin is the richness of each NPC. Each NPCs have unique stories to tell that will definitely pull your heartstrings. Every time you interact with each NPC, you will learn more about them and eventually fall in love with their stories,

Lastly, the versatility of this game lets players pick and choose the difficulty they want. You have the freedom to do whatever you want in your farm. Plus, the availability of modding in this game is wide enough to fulfill your dreams of customizing how your game works.

There's always something new to explore and the NPCs are very fleshed out characters to build relationships with. Definitely recommend to people who enjoy calm games and also grinding games. But it also has a great abundance of ways to play it and you are not forced into anything. Also, super beautiful graphics and serine music.

Playing Stardew Valley is like stepping into a charming, pixelated world where the stress of daily life melts away. The game beautifully combines farm simulation with RPG elements, creating an absorbing rural world. It’s not just about farming, it’s about the interconnectedness of the community and the land.

Starting my farm was a slow process, but it was rewarding to see it grow from a few parsnips to a bustling source of income. The game is relaxed and lets you grow at your own pace, but it’s a rich world once you get past the slow first season. The blend of RPG and farm sim feels effortless, and it makes Stardew Valley exciting and compelling without being stressful.

However, the game is not without its flaws. The days in Stardew Valley are short, and there’s always so much to do. Between farming, fishing, mining, and befriending the townsfolk, it can feel like there’s never enough time. It’s also easy to become overwhelmed by the sheer amount of activities and options available.

Despite these challenges, Stardew Valley is a game that keeps me coming back. There’s always something new to discover, a new crop to plant, or a new area to explore. It’s a game that offers endless fun, addictive gameplay, and a sense of accomplishment that’s hard to find elsewhere. It’s not just a game, it’s a home away from home.

It's a great game but man, the controls are not logical and you still have to minimise out to use a wiki or google to know what to do in some cases...lovely, well made game but I'm not giving out positive reviews when I have to constantly refer to the internet...game needs more info around the simple tasks. Also, a UI that was better laid out and easier to navigate would make a big difference. I've found myself using keyboard and mouse as well as a controller as using the controller 100% of the time is just chaos when using some of the menus. This really should be looked at! It's amazing the games has come this far and the interface still feels ancient. Considering the game revolves around time, respecting the player's ability to organise would really, really help reduce stress.

An example of how the game forces you to use the wiki's:

Upgrading Watering Can - You go to the Blacksmith to upgrade your tools but it never mentions that you can upgrade your watering can. Now when I leave the house I put my watering can in a chest to save inventory space but keep my Sword, Axe, Pick Axe and Hoe. I'm on Year 3 and at no point did I see a way of upgrading my watering can at the Blacksmiths as the option was never offered. Now I've learnt you only get offered upgrades for what you are holding!! So the game never mentions this at all...no doubt obvious to some but to me I never would have taken my watering can there as it never needs to leave the farm!?!?!

Finishing Off Community Centre? Need animal products? Why is getting the right eggs a mystery?? Where's the explanation on how to get large eggs?? How do you get white eggs if the two chickens you have are brown?? Off to the Wiki..."to get a white chicken just cancel the purchase process when buying a new chicken until you get the chicken you want!!!" Well game...why not just let the player choose what colour chicken they want when they are buying them?? Would it be that hard...???

As for the GUI, It's like an adult made the game and let their kids make the GUI (graphical user interface)...absolutely ruins any enjoyment when I end up screaming at how unusable every, single menu is! And having a control scheme whereby one button does multiple functions...fine in other games but in this it just makes interacting/using items a risk if you're too quick and are not aware of what you've got selected in your inventory!!!

Losing equipment due to "Weeds have destroyed parts of your farm" message sucks especially when there were no weeds around the effected area. In one case for me, two barrels making Starfruit Wine got taken out when they were set next to my house with no weeds, no trees, no grass, no seeds, no wood and no stones around them. Amazing how a weed can take out a wooden barrel overnight!! 

Lightning is also annoying as despite having over a dozen lightning rods installed around the perimeter of my plots I still lose crops in storms...usually Starfruits!! This goes against the relaxing nature of the game as all of a sudden you are questioning your farm setup but yet you have no stats or info to fall back on. Would it not be cool to have an item that shows the effective area of scarecrows and lightning rods???

Harvesting large crops becomes tedious with no offered solution to speed up the process over time. A lot of my frustration with the game comes from it feeling comparable to a mobile game that looks to keep you playing but only really offers a long grind to feel a sense of progress. Want iridium?? Well, that alone has taken me over 1 game year to prep for due to needing 99 stones to make 1 staircase!! In one afternoon I could get around 300 pieces of stone. And when approaching the Skull Cave you'll want to have 99 steps at least. These 99 steps will require you to grab just under 10,000 stones!!! And there is nowhere to farm stones other than the quarry which is basically utter rubbish as it renews too slowly. Next option is mining and when you don't even get a stone from every rock you break I hope you can see that the mid to late game is basically a huge, repetitive grind.

Most of the game mechanics are decent. The time/day cycle really motivates you to prioritise what you need to get done although I still think the game would benefit from extending the length of a day by about 10-15%. Trying to attack everything at once will stress you out. Pick what you want to do and stick to it knowing another year will roll by allowing you to address things that you missed out on the first time round. It rarely feels comfortable though as if you want to get a lot done you'll soon end up rushing around...

Not finding much excitement mid-game...new stuff doesn't really impact you much or offer any new and exciting changes. Machines like the recycler just get boring and pointless after a short while. Would be nice if everything had more purpose and made more impact. I have chests full of "stuff" that I've kept as I don't know what use it serves. Looking online at the wiki it does feel like MOST of what's there isn't used for ANYTHING! In most cases they are used for dyes?!?! So few options for a survival game...compared to say...Terraria where everything you collect has a purpose.

Heart's in the right place...just needs someone on the team who can smooth off the rough edges and maybe add a bit more depth to some of the games mechanics...

I think Stardew Valley 2 will be amazing...just as long as the guy making it employs more people to help.

Ideas:

Would love to see more focus on Hops and have more varieties to choose from. Craft Ale is very popular these days and to have access to different hops (Azaca, Citra, Mozaic, Galaxy) and some different brewing solutions to make Porters, Stouts, Lager and Ales would be very do-able. Same for wine and other beverages....

Would love to see better clothing with buffs early/mid game that improve walking speed. Coffee is such a joke and it really shouldn't be so hard to walk a bit faster!

There's a desperate need to make harvesting big plots more enjoyable. Picking each item one by one only serves to extend game time...nothing else!!! Absolute misery at the moment...especially with blue berries!!

Hoses?? Could hoses be implemented to water your beans/hops??

Horse manure? Could we have access (late game) to fertiliser that grows quicker and increases quality AND lasts two seasons???

Starting a new season is never enjoyable with a big farm. There needs to be tools available that allow more ground to be covered quickly. Hoe'ing each tile manually after 6 years farming seems wrong.

Manual switch for sprinklers?? How about letting us turn on the sprinklers manually???

## Stardew Valley: Ruined My Actual Life (10/10)

**Pros:**

* Chickens. So many chickens.
* Highly addictive. Seriously, I haven't seen sunlight in days. My crops are thriving, but my vitamin D deficiency is not.
* Finally achieved my lifelong dream of becoming a hat connoisseur.
* Single-handedly revived the local economy by becoming a pumpkin overlord.
* Lewis lowkey creeps me out, but hey, free parsnips.

**Cons:**

* Therapist bills are skyrocketing thanks to my crippling emotional attachment to fictional pixelated characters.
* Crops are more demanding than my actual children.
* Developed an unhealthy obsession with mayonnaise. 
* Sold my soul to Joja Corporation for that sweet, sweet auto-grabber. Deep regrets.
* Still haven't figured out how to talk to Elliot without sounding like a lovesick fool.

**Overall:**

This game is both a blessing and a curse. It's the perfect escape from reality, but be warned: you may lose yourself in the pixelated utopia of Stardew Valley. Just don't blame me when your real-life plants die because you're too busy watering your virtual pumpkins.

**Additional Notes:**

* 100% recommend romancing Penny. Best girl, hands down.
* Beware the dangers of the Skull Cavern. I may or may not have sacrificed several cows to appease the RNG gods.
* ConcernedApe, please add more hat options. I need more hats. 

**P.S.** Morris can shove it. Joja forever. (Just kidding, please don't come for me, Joja hitmen.)

I have had this game since it came out, I've played it on my switch, xbox, this laptop and my old laptop plus my PC. I love this game, it's got it's own charm. When it first came out I saw it was like the harvest moon/story of season games, and honestly I loved this more for many reasons. 

- the mods (eventually) made more game. I had done so much in the OG game that I got tired of it after a while, this year i picked it up and added mods and it added SO much more to do it was nuts. 
- The characters feel more like real people they made sense. I enjoy good character development 
- the story is optional, you don't have to be the nature lover, you can pick jojo, or nither of them. It's interesting. (i'm a never jojo gang) 
- the things you can have and do, the amount of machines, animals, things you can do. It's crazy how much is in this game to do and grind for. 
- the farming, mining, fishing, dungons, festivals and more. 

there's way more to point out but it's a very fun game. I enjoy the pixel art work too, it's something not a lot of people do much anymore but I like the styles of it all. 

This game is STILL getting updates, new content and more love then any game I've played since. I love this game and it's so sweet the guy loves the game too. 

So I would say, please try it if you like calming gaming that let's you just pick some blueberries, forage some mushrooms and get to know all the people because it's nice to just chill out and walk around. 

I could say so much more but, if your looking at my comments your probably already thinking about getting it, i'm telling you you should! It's great, <3 A game I will always go back to.

After playing for over 180 hours, I want to say that this game is amazing. This game has alot of content to entertain you. When you complete perfection (it takes ALOT of time only to complete it),  you cand head to unlocking achievements, make some challenges for yourself or just chill. The vanilla game will take you alot of time, but when you get bored, you can start a new save, or even download amazing mods from nexus, that will entertain you in every way possible! Starting from visuals, ending on the mods that move the game to the whole different level, this game is very hard to get boring. For example: one of the most popular mods is stardew valley expanded, which adds new characters, new locations, new items e.t.c....
ConcernedApe is the creator of this game, and i must say he is an amazing developer. He made ALMOST everything by himself, that means the music, coding, art, ideas are all from him and only him (I can't deny that he could get some ideas from his friends, or community though). He is a really talented person, and he also works on a new game called haunted chocolaiter! I wish him the best, and I am sure there is a lot waiting for him in his journey.

Great game to play when you are either bored, stressed, or just want to play a game that doesn't require much attention to detail. A lot of people will want to play games that have these amazing graphics, diverse story lines and characters, and more. In Stardew, you have options as to what you want to do. You can pick between farming, fishing, mining, combat, animals, or even relationships with some of the NPC's. 

It's a laid back game, and if you want to go above and beyond? you can go through Nexusmods and go from Stardew Valley to Stardew Expanded with more characters, bigger map, and more! All in all, great game to play whether it's single player, or if you want to play with others. Can't wait for Haunted Chocolatier to be released!

I've played this game through several times with breaks between.  It's very well done and even after being out for quite some time, the dev is still very much involved.  Each time I come back after a longer break there seems to be more content.  Cute story, lots of interpersonal chat with NPCs, and a choice of type of farm so you can have different layouts / challenges / bonuses each time.
Can be a bit grindy before you start getting upgrades but that's true with most of this style game.
I personally find the fishing tough until I get upgraded but there is a training rod you can buy that is pretty forgiving, i only allows basic fish but good to get the skill up.  Mining does involve fighting, but I can manage it and I'm really bad at that sort of thing.
One pet peeve is that if you accidentally click on something in a store you can't reverse it.  
There are some pretty heavy story lines for the NPC's, just a heads up especially if you're thinking of this for young kids.  It's nice to have realism and not all rainbows and butterflies, and this is not a complaint at all, but it caught me a bit off guard.  Nicely handled though.
Overall a fantastic game with great dev support.  Highly recommend.

I thought I would like this game. I always hear people ranting about it and it has a lot of elements from other games I like. Farming, fishing, combat, romance- And much, much more! But that kind of became it's crux unfortunate for me. There's too damn much! It feels overwhelming, like a job more then a game. Maybe it would work better with a more slow introduction to each of those elements, but still I think the exhaustion system would still make me feel like I need to rush everything to get back to base. The romance element is more subjective, I know a lot of people love the romance options in this game but I honestly did not find a single one charming. I know people love this game, and I don't want to deny it has good elements. But I just really couldn't get into it.

I think Stardew valley is a okay-ish relaxing game. I love the bachelors, especially Sebastian. But sometimes I did find myself getting bored. The dialogue isn't enough for me and I hate how we can only get a sentence from some of the bachelors. For me, there isn't really much to do. I had to install mods in order to keep playing the game because it was so plain. After modding the game, I really did like it. But I'm pretty sure without the mods, I wouldn't have even bothered playing after 5 hours. If you want the game because its famous and/or some of your friends play it I'd recommend installing some mods. It doesn't take that long. But if you want a game worth your time. SUN HAVEN!!

While I do take breaks nowadays for other games I still end up wandering back to this masterpiece every so often to play with mods that expand the main game to make things interesting again.

I'm going on 1000 hrs in Stardew soon...so it goes without saying that I recommend it wholeheartedly. The developer has consistently supported the community, releasing LARGE free updates with lots of new content and works with modders to maintain a robust modding community. Stardew Valley is a game about farming look like harvest moon, but there are more adventures awaiting curious players beyond cultivating a rich and bountiful garden. From mining and fishing to making friends and falling in love, Stardew Valley's Pelican Town is stuffed with rewarding opportunities. As modern day woes give way to pressing matters on the farm and within your newfound community, Stardew Valley's meditative activities often lead to personal reflection in the real world. It’s a game that tugs at your curiousity as often as it does your heart. This game recomended and funniest to play.

I picked Stardew Valley up when it first started getting popular. A few of my friends had just bought the game, and I thought the game looked really cute, so I did as well. Let me just tell you, that might have been one of the best decisions of my life.

This game is more of a lifestyle than a game. Everything feels so good, from working your farm, to standing still for 15 minutes doing nothing but fishing. Planting and nourishing your crops, interracting with the NPC's and engaging in cute events all makes this game the world to me. So many days and nights were spent having an absolute blast, and I felt like this game really touched my heart. I felt genuinely excited when the NPC's liked the gifts I gave them for their birthday. I was intrigued mining further and further down the caves. I was scared when hearing noises in the night, and I felt genuine joy and togetherness during the seasonal events.
I don't think any other game has ever hit home for me in such a way, and I hope everyone at some point gets the pleasure of immersing themselves in this absolute gem of a game.

[i]Thank you Chucklefish, for granting me this amazing, humbling and heartwarming experience. Thank you so very much.[/i]

Stardew Valley is an absolute gem of a game, one that effortlessly stole nearly 200 hours of my life - and I cherished almost every moment of it. It's a captivating blend of farming, life simulation, and adventure, set in a charming pixel-art world that's as inviting as it is vast.

One thing to note is that Stardew Valley does lean quite a bit on its wiki. But given the game's depth and complexity, this reliance is not just understandable but somewhat necessary. There's a richness in its mechanics, from farming and crafting to relationships and exploration, that makes consulting the wiki feel more like delving into a treasure map than a chore.

What truly makes Stardew Valley stand out is how it balances its various elements. Whether you're tending to your crops, fishing by the lakeside, exploring mysterious caves, or building relationships with the townsfolk, there's a sense of peace and accomplishment in every task. The game's ability to blend simplicity with depth is a rare find.

Overall, I'd give Stardew Valley a well-deserved 9/10. It's a game that offers a delightful escape into a world that feels both nostalgic and new, a world where every day brings a small, new adventure. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or a casual player, Stardew Valley has something to offer everyone, making it a must-play title in any library.

And Amazing game that is both fun to enjoy and master, there is also a lot of support from the fanbase of the game so you can find good tips. However, once you master the game it could negatively affect its replayability. So if you can mod the game, then mod it after a first play-through is my recommendation, however the joy of the game is that you can play how you like, it is a single player game and multi-player is not naturally competitive. Plus take your time, the game is approachable and don’t feel like you need to rush things. Miss out on something in one season? then wait till it returns to get it when you are at a better level and overall skill.

Я думала это люди рофлили когда говорили, что зависимы от Стардью. Как выясняется, нет. 
Игра достаточно однообразная, но в самом однообразии я как-то и нашла свой шарм. Просто сидишь, садишь картошку, ловишь рыбу, и обязательно гладишь свою собаку, и опционально детей. Даже несмотря на повторение геймплея из раза в раз, игра все равно предоставляет разные цели, которые ты можешь поставить сам для себя (например поженится на всех партнерах возможных, накопить миллион или сделать идеальный дом). Я после первого года еще установила модификации на игру, в основном косметические, однако все равно они очень сильно обновили для меня всю игру в целом. Однако, если вы только планируете начать играть, не скачиваете модификации как Stardew Valley Expanded. В начале вам и так будет весьма сложно, так эта модификация добавляет еще очень много других вещей, за которыми надо следить. 
В общем, я свои впечатления высказала, надеюсь кому-нибудь это поможет с решением покупки этой игры 
(но не скачиваете, если у вас реально есть жизнь)

I purchased this game a couple of years ago, and initially, I struggled to have fun with it. But I played this game every time after i go outside even if its only for a couple of hours or so. Since then, I've found myself completely engrossed, often losing track of time as I immerse myself in its captivating world. I wholeheartedly endorse it; it has become my ultimate go-to for relaxation and entertainment over these past couple of years. One of the standout features of the game is its charming and appealing art style, which instantly draws players into its world. Moreover, the game boasts a delightful ensemble of characters, each with their unique personalities and quirks, making every interaction a joyous experience. What truly sets this game apart, however, is its sheer depth and breadth of content. There are countless activities to engage in, each offering its own set of challenges and rewards. Whether it's tending to a virtual farm, exploring vast landscapes, or building relationships with in-game characters, there's always something new and exciting to discover and pursue.

In game time passes way to quickly for you ever to get the feeling on progression. Before you can figure out what your doing its bedtime and if you don't go it'll cost you cash and then you wake up in your cabin. 
Fishing just doesn't work for me. I tried several times only ever catching a fish on my first attempt but I didn't see how I did it as every other time it got away. In the end I just couldn't be bothered wasting the short time before bed.
There is also a lack of explaining when you progress in crafting. It will tell you you can do something new or make it but not what it's for. You really do have to figure everything out yourself with the days flying past and winter is on you before you've got to greenhorn.
If that is what you love this is for you but when the graphics are eight bit at best then you really want the game to offer more of a chance for you to have enough opportunity to get below the fifth level in the mine before bed.

If you liked Harvest moon back in 2005 this game is for you. It both emulates and overwhelmingly outclasses Harvest Moon and Harvest Moon adjacent game.

The pixel art is not good: a mess of anti-alias and non-anti-alias, various sized pixels, not aligned, so sprites fall between other pixels. The controls are awkward on a keyboard/mouse setup: depending on where you left click, your character will spin around and do actions in places you don't want, so you have to make sure to left click far away from your character to keep them doing actions in front of them (such as swinging a sword), otherwise, they'll swing randomly. No intuitive gameplay: you'll often look up the comprehensive Wiki, because things in the game don't make sense. Way too much grind. A game shouldn't leave you feeling that you want the hours back that you spent playing it, and that's how I feel, so that's why I'm down-voting. I've played similar games and got far more enjoyment in far less time.

Harvest Moon nostalgia plus combat.  Live your dream!  You can:  own your own home, work your own hours, make friends, get married, build a life in a community, make enough money to live, help little alien-creatures save the town (or sell out to corporate greed,) fish in a difficult fishing minigame, hit slimes with swords, get wrecked by dinosaurs, and/or whatever you want.  Enjoy the peace and pace of single-player or the absolute chaos of multiplayer!  A truly exceptional game made by a creator who deeply cares for the project.

Stardew Valley is probably as perfect to a perfect game as you can get.

I've come to this title expecting to play a casual farming game, that actually has a soul and a caring indie dev/devs behind it and, to my suprise, it outgrew my expectations exponentially.
Farming is just a small portion of what you can do in this game. There's also mining, foraging, combat and fishing, everything is simple but with at least some depth. We'll get to these later.

There are villagers to which you can talk to and some you can even get married with. They are written suprisingly well and while everything seems peaceful, calm and colorful in this game, there are also mature and not all too family-friendly topics brought up, [spoiler]Shane's alcoholism, Lewis' misuse of tax money or Kent's war PTSD[/spoiler] just to name a few. 

Farming - The main attraction of this game, is of course, the most developed mechanic. There's a lot of crops to choose from, some buyable, some obtainable by other methods. Each has its own purpose, more or less profitable for the player. They grow in different seasons with different speed, some can be harvested multiple times and some stay to the next season. It bugs me off that some crops don't have a good reason to be in the game, aside from [spoiler]dishes for 100% completion[/spoiler] but otherwise, I have nothing to complain about.

Foraging - It's functionality boils down to making farming more profitable via some unlocks that levelling up provides, as foraging itself isn't really profitable and doesn't feel as deep as Farming and Combat but it's there and it helps considerably despite not being that good on its own.

Combat - You wouldn't expect a farming game to have a fairly complex combat system, however Stardew's Combat has much depth to it. There are different types of weapons, armor, knockback, swing speed, buffs, rings and even [spoiler]enchants[/spoiler].

Mining - There are caves and minerals you can mine in them. Mining is a bit more complex than foraging as it allows you to mine in different ways and is necessary to upgrade your tools to progress and/or make some actions easier to do. Gems obtained from mining can also be used to help in farming, combat or mining itself to make insane profit.

Fishing - Isn't that profitable or complex but can aid the player in other activities by providing buffs from some food that needs fish and is just fun.

There are several things I'm not a big fan of but I think they come more from the general premise of the game, as a consequence of of some features generally regarded as good and me as a person. I found myself having SV's gamepedia open all the time while playing because the clock's always ticking and there are things to be done before the next season or some major milestones you want to achieve now because the premise of exploring a new zone or simply because they're really helpful. There's a lot of routine and very little time in the beginning, everything feels so slow and once you reach a certain point in the game with some powerful tools, you'll probably have a hard time coming back to the beginning and replaying the game, especially after [spoiler]reaching perfection and seeing the cutscene[/spoiler]. This game offers replayability but after 100%-ting my first save, it just gives me the vibes that it's time to move on.

So, why did I say Stardew Valley is so close to being the perfect game?
Because it gives you so much freedom in what and how you want to achieve it. It's by no means an ultimate sandbox game but offers many things to do nonetheless, you can even cheat your way to 100% and the game will reassure you that nothing bad happened and you should just have fun. There are monsters to fight, areas to explore, materials and crops to gather. And there's also an alive modding community (not on Steam Workshop) that continues to create content for the players to enjoy.

Thank you for making this game ConcernedApe. I hope for the best for you and for everything you have planned to be as great of a success as Stardew is.

Good farming game, cosy, a lot of NPC and lore to discover ! Lot of customisation too, and it's really cool to play it with your friends :)
However, I have mixed feelings about certain aspects : in multiplayer, the time in a day that continues even during dialogs is really frustrating, because the days are really short : you can spend 2h of an in game day watering crops or talking to a single NPC... Time is counted and you are punished by the game if you go to bed too late, it clashes a lot with the cosy aspect in my opinion, you can feel like you can't take your time
Moreover, the stamina bar is spent really fast especially at the beginning. There are days where you chop 2 trees and water some crops, and it's already 4pm, and you don't even have the stamina anymore to do other things...
Asides these frustrating aspects, the game is really nice and you have a good time, I just wish these things were more balanced for a better experience !

It's a really addicting game once you get the hang of it. Surprisingly the farm that I got the furthest on was the ocean farm. This game has it's challenges too. It's best to play with friends if you are having difficulties playing alone. That's how I got the hang of it is playing with friends then I branched out to my own farm and it was a lot better. Then it got more difficult as I approached year 3 and had my deluxe barn, coop, greenhouse etc...but now I am ready for that challenge. You can even court and marry one of the town's singles no matter the gender. Once you marry though and if you don't pay attention to your spouse they'll get angry at you. Tip: give your spouse kisses everyday and I would still give them two presents every week. I could go on with this game...but the only negative I could give on this game that's bad is that some ppl have an issue with multiplayer farms. The host is fine but sometimes your friends who are playing can get kicked randomly and then they lose all their progress on your farm. This isn't everyone though and this seems to only happen on PC. If you own this game on another platform and your friends are local with also the same platform...try to make a farm on that. This should not deter anyone from playing this game. It's still very enjoyable whether single player or coop. I still highly recommend this game!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This was my very first RPG and I'm 48 yrs old.  At first I got a little frustrated because I was playing on a Chromebook and using the mousepad for everything including fishing.  Then, once I played the game all the way through and met all the achievements and did all the activities, my husband upgraded my system to a Linux, and I was playing SDV on Steam.  Before I had to sell my gaming computer, I had learned about modding and was running 70 mods and playing co-op with hubby.  Fast forward to now, and we've hit hard times, so for the last 2 years I played on an old Chromebook with 38 mods.  I learned how to mod on my own in about 2 days.  The hardest part was sorting which mods were compatible with Android.  Now, I'm running just SDV on a Dell laptop running Windows 10 Pro, and I'm having to learn everything all over.  I just installed SDV 3 days ago, and I'm still learning Windows since I haven't used it since Windows 7.  It's been a very long time since I've dabbled in Microsoft.  LOL  I wanted to say all this to encourage new people to try this game no matter how much computer experience they have because if I can do it, more than likely they can do it too.  The ability to mod this game makes it insanely more interesting to me and the possibilities are endless, not to mention the fact that Concerned Ape is fantastic and adding buttloads of new content when he updates the original game.  I highly recommend you try this game.  Love you all!

I never would've thought I'll ever enjoy playing a farm-related game, yet here I am, because Stardew is SO MUCH MORE than just gathering your harvests and feeding animals, and I don't regret giving it a shot. The game's pixel-art graphics and lovely scenery captured my heart <3 It has awesome mechanics - there are many activities you can choose from, besides of taking care of your farm, such as fishing, exploring the caves and slaying monsters, seeking for artifacts, taking part in various festivals throughout the year, or befriending NPC's which are, by the way, amazingly well-written and each of them has a unique personality (you can marry some of them as well! or even have kids with them later). There's pretty much always something to do, so you can't get bored of it for long, looong hours. I still haven't discovered everything the game has to offer, but from the beginning it made a HUGE positive impression on me. 10/10 WORDS CANNOT DESCRIBE MY LOVE FOR STARDEW VALLEY

This is my favorite game! The music is great, the art style is lovely, and I like that I can choose to do quests or kinda just have fun decorating my farm and chatting with the townsfolk depending on what mood I'm in. The game also has good replay-ability: between the different farm types, the option to support the community center or Joja, and the different relationships you can form with NPCs there's all kinds of different paths to take in each save. If you're considering getting this game, I would highly recommend it!

After investing more than 1000 hours into the enchanting world of Stardew Valley, I can confidently say that this game is my absolute favorite. For me, Stardew Valley is not just a game; it's a tranquil escape... an adventure to go on and explore possibilities. The developer/creator, Concerned Ape, actually listens to the input of fans. This is what I feel sets Stardew Valley apart. This gesture makes every aspect of the game feel meaningful. 

Stardew Valley is a game that has profoundly impacted my gaming experience. It's a testament to the creativity and dedication of its developer and a shining example of what indie games can achieve. For those who have yet to experience its charm, I cannot recommend it enough. Stardew Valley is not just a game to play; it's a world to live in, a community to be a part of, and an adventure that continues to unfold. Here's to the next thousand hours!

1000% would recommend this game to those who like cozy little farming sims because this is the definition of that. Its so much fun trying to up the amount of money you earn each day with also talking to the villagers. The villagers also might be one of my favorite parts about this game. You get to have a chance to gain or loose hearts with someone and when gaining hearts you gain more of their friendship and different dialog. Also each and every character (romanceable or non- romanceable) has such a distinct personality and it just makes you even more warped up in this wonderful game. Stardew Valley has been my favorite game for years and no doubt will continue to be. To put it short, Stardew Valley is a wonderful, cozy farming simulator that drags you into its tiny little universe after a hard day in the real world.

One of the most relaxing and enjoyable games I've ever played. Hours of raising animals, tending to crops, and crafting artisan goods. Makes you nostalgic for a more simple time. Be warned, too much time on this game may cause you to purchase chickens and start an herb garden.

- Good if you want a game that's chill and you can sink heaps of time into
- I like the world and characters
- The artstyle is cool, good music
- Lots of stuff to do

The negatives of this game for me are that it's annoying having to walk back to my bed at the end of each day, feeling too constrained by how quickly the day passes, and not being able to save the game whenever you want, only when you sleep.

My girlfriend told me to buy this game and I laughed at her. almost 50 hrs later my monopoly over the produce in Pelican Town exceeds anything the pitiful Joja Corporation could have ever dreamed of. The people of the Valley shudder in terror at my goat cheese operation. Robin cowers in the corner of my farm, hammering the nails into my fifth wine shed. I have spoken to none of the villagers. I am nobody's friend. No one accepts my hand at the flower dance as I am not here to make acquaintances. I exist purely to plant ancient seeds, Milk my farm animals and produce mayonnaise. 

Rarely, I speak to Clint... the man who shatters my geodes into gems and other resources by the bucket load. yet the friendly faces of Pelican town smile and bring warmth to my soul. Stardew Valley is the only experience I need in my life. 9.5/10. I just wish Pierre would open on Wednesdays.

Stardew valley is a masterpiece 
 
especially for ConcernedApe being an indie dev

but heres a few pros and cons!

pros.
1. amazing story, gameplay and surprisingly a lot of lore for what could seem like a regular farming game from the outside
2. not being too automated (this might be seen as a con for some people) 
this is a farm not a factory
3. a lot of content and things to do (even more up and coming content)
cons.
1. Alex
2. some story problems with Joja
- they never really seem like a threat to the way the valley functioned
3. never really expanded on the fantasy aspects that the modern world was built on top of

it is relaxing is fun you can play it how ever you like you can raise animals grow foods go mining and while mining fight monsters you can also get married to any of the one's that are single in the game and make friends with everyone as far as ik you can also have 2 kids in the game and also if you don't want to marry one of the npc's you can marry your friend if you play with them, if you want to play it with mods that's possible but as for me I just like playing it the way it comes as how the Developer Concerned Ape made it to be also if any twitch or youtuber tells you to not clear your farm fully of everything just ignore them cause the grass will always grow back after a while also if you plant tree's in rows spaced by 2 over you can have 10 trees per row and if repeat this you can have endless wood just make sure to replant the saplings when you chop down the tree's so you never run out I love this game 10/10 for me.

Its good but it kind of feels like a childs game.

Bad:
-Too much community involvement. Sometimes I just want to farm and be left alone
-Either too little stamina or tasks take too much energy. Coupled with how long it takes to get food production online its more annoying than anything. Many days ended at like 2pm
-Items/upgrades insanely expensive in the early game, then way too cheap later on. Money ramp is weird.
-Takes forever to get to a place where you reasonably defend yourself against threats
-Can't move player homes
-Cant customize outside of house or choose design/location at start

Good:
-Farming/Resource gathering mechanics are fun and despite being repetitive don't get too boring
-Progression and sense of achievement when you get upgrades feels nice
-Fun with friends

Overall:
Its alright. Not really dark enough and without the ability to play hermit it doesn't really feel like its for me. Graveyard Keepers (Cemetery version of Stardew Valley) feels more up my alley.

I'm absolutely obsessed with this game. It's like a warm hug for your mind and soul. If you're in need of something relaxing, laid-back, and ever dreamt of being a farmer or even a fisherman, or if you've ever wanted to pet a cow and name it "Buttercup or "Moo-lisa" then this game is a must-buy. I'm a huge fan of Sebastian. He's the epitome of cold, anti-social, and emo in Stardew Valley, and I've spent countless hours stalking him and even sending him some of my chicken eggs. Despite the fact that he hates both me and the eggs, I'm determined to make him fall head over heels for me and then shatter his heart by marrying my boyfriend in the game. Totally worth every penny. 100% recommended.

tl;dr This game is fantastic. You're doing yourself a disservice by not playing it. Worth it full price.

Long version:

Stardew Valley is a great game. I was honestly a little unsure going on, and I waited a while to buy it. But I regret not buying it much sooner.

The game is easy to pick up and approachable, even if you're an expert or a novice with farming sims.
A single playthrough can last a long time, but it never feels dragged out. The game is always at your pace. And the progression in the game is fantastic. On your first in-game day your farm is completely overrun by weeds, rocks, and trees. And your farmhouse is all beat up and small. Day by day you keep working on it and suddenly without realizing you have a massive plot of land with crop fields and a huge house with a kitchen and master bedroom. The progression of the game is amazing. And you can choose how you spend your in-game day. There are lots of sub skills like fishing, mining, and foraging. All of which get easier as you level.

There are in game town events and life-sim aspects like marriage or cooking. All of which breathe life into the world. Most are optional to a degree. NPCs all have schedules, personality, and identities.

And of course, this game still receives free content updates. Some of which are expansion sized. Nowadays, most games will charge $30 or more a DLC for that. But the developer cares about this game and wants it to be it's best.

Stardew is really easy to just pick up and play, get lost in, before you realize you were playing this for hours and had a blast. And you keep playing because this game has such a great gameplay loop. It's also very replayable which makes it fantastic to come back to every couple months.

My main complaints with the game, and these are nitpicks not really "cons" are:
- The games leveling/xp system does not say how much xp you need/have which can make leveling a chore
- NPC socializing could be a bit expanded on. It's mostly just give the NPC the right gifts and say hi to them everyday. If you're good at that there isn't much else and you can get the NPC events pretty easy. There isn't any deep choices or decisions for the most part
and lastly
- The game almost requires a wiki. The game has some tools like an in-game calendar. But it's really advised to use a wiki. I wish there was more in-game tools for it rather than just Google-ing it.

Again those are just nitpicks that could be improved in an update or in the developer's next game: Haunted Chocolatier

I had this game on the Switch lite and have bought it on my pc last year. It's such a fun game that with my hours on the Switch and the PC rack up to around 300 or so hours playing the game. Took around 200 hours on the Switch before I decided to get the game on my pc so I can also explore with mods and play multiplayer with my friends. The great thing is after I was tired playing with keyboard and mouse on steam, I got a Nintendo controller and was able to connect it to steam. I found a controller layout made for playing stardew using the nintendo controls :D so I didn't even need to learn the steam controller setup. Highly recommend !

Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8–10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you’ve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don’t leave them too long or they’ll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

This type of game is not everyone's cup of tea, I get it. But if you do like slower paced games (or games like Animal Crossing), this is an awesome game to play. 

There is so many ways to "play": completionist, min/maxers, focus on farming vs focus on mining, playing the vanilla game vs mods

This game has a great and active online community. Great mods are created for this - quality of life, aesthetic, cheats, expansions. 

You can truly make this game yours

Of note, despite having created this game YEARS ago, Concerned Ape is STILL producing new content - without putting it behind a pay wall.    

And given the hours of play time I had through this game, I would buy it all over again in a heart beat

Hoo, boy. Here we go again. Yet another "farming simulator" that forces you to grind for months if not years in real life on end just to get to a point where you can enjoy the ENTIRE "intended" point of the game itself: to relax and enjoy life on the farm. This is arguably amongst the most damning reasons why the average person (or even the average gamer, for that matter) chooses to stick with AAA games despite the apparent controversy and "facts" online; the fact that folks only play games like this not to enjoy them, but to "achieve perfection" and get to the very end.

Remember: it's not about the destination, it's about the journey as a whole. As always, there is no offense to Eric Barone (ConcernedApe) for his hard work on the game himself, particularly as an individual himself, but clearly, with him describing Stardew Valley as a "relaxing farming life simulator," he doesn't even understand his own term for what the game is supposed to be at all. In fact, the recent updates (including and especially the upcoming 1.6 update) have only added on to the already-excruciating grind that had been present since the very beginning of the game itself, and an average new player in its then-1.6 state would be turned away from the game and refunded before two hours have even been put into this title.

Overall, I'd rather be playing Story of Seasons: A Wonderful Life right now than this. Sure, it might not have all, if any, of the bells and whistles of Stardew Valley, with only a linear path to the top, but as I've said many times before: Simple ≠ Easy. Sure, setting up your farm in SV might be simple, but good luck getting it exactly the way you want. Meanwhilst, SoS:AWL may not be all that simple on the surface, but it's sure as sunshine easy for even newbies to figure out for themselves, and thus really get themselves into the game before long, as will later and even older titles in the franchise (and its tough-as-nails spin-off of the original's namesake, literally Harvest Moon) such as Rune Factory and the original Harvest Moon: A Wonderful Life. In fact, Story of Seasons: A Wonderful Life is in fact a remake of the game I've just mentioned; I'd check it out myself if you have the time. For now, stay well clear of this game right'ere, and everything associated with it. Trust me, you'll be glad you didn't get yourself involved in all this "farming" like it's "the last game you'll ever play" like it's Dreamworld or somethin' like that. There's never a one-size-fits-all for gaming, and certainly not for this one.

I've put off reviewing this game for more than a year because i just don't know where to start, and by the time I'm done, this is gonna be a mammoth of a review. It's now 2am and for the past month I've been in one of my stardew hyperfixation cycles again, so now's a good time. 

And for the record, if the pixelated art style is off-putting to you, it was for me too in the beginning. You learn to love it, you just have to get used to it first :)

I was the biggest harvest moon fan growing up, and it still holds a disproportionately huge place in my heart, so I know I'm probably biased, and the target demographic, but even when i look at this game from an entirely critical perspective, it's still something to marvel at. ConcernedApe is a superhuman, a modern day Michelangelo. It's incredible the difference it makes when a game is designed by a person who understands what people want and listens to feedback. The modders for this game hold an equally special place in my heart. Unlike games like Sims 4, you actually don't need mods in order to play a fun, satisfying game, but the mods in themselves are absolute art and the ones who create them deserve more recognition.

Just everything about this game is just right. It's found an impeccable balance between having direction, and still giving you freedom and an open world to do whatever you want. It gives you things like quests and goals to strive to achieve, an implied direction for you to take your farm in, but there's never any pressure or real consequences if you want to take a little longer or do things differently. You have the freedom to be an absolute menace or just a regular lil farmer pal. I mean, who's to stop you from turning your farm into a coal production facility or something? Not Mayor Lewis, he can barely manage his own affairs...

I won't beat the dead horse of raving about the characters, the depth and the surprising rawness portrayed in this game, since several before me have already done that. I just want to express my gratitude that this game was made, and if theres an afterlife, I hope I get to play stardew in it.

Stardew Valley stands out as an absolute gem, a gaming experience that has captivated me across various consoles. This farming RPG is not just a mere favourite; it has evolved into a delightful distraction, providing countless hours of pure gaming bliss.

The visuals are charming and nostalgically crafted, reminiscent of the golden age of 16-bit graphics. The pixel art's meticulous attention to detail is truly breathtaking, and the vibrant colors breathe life into the Stardew Valley universe.

Now, let's delve into the gameplay – an enthralling journey where you inherit a dilapidated farm and embark on a quest to revive it from its dismal state. The ability to customize your farm, cultivate crops, care for animals, and forge intricate relationships with the townsfolk is incredibly satisfying.

What elevates Stardew Valley far above typical farming simulations is its profound depth and diverse range of activities. It serves as a virtual playground, offering a plethora of options, whether you're mining for valuable resources or peacefully casting a line into serene lakes. Every season introduces new challenges and opportunities, ensuring the gameplay remains a constant source of freshness.

And then there's the soundtrack – a symphony of perfection. The tranquil melodies seamlessly blend with the game's calming atmosphere, transforming routine tasks like tending to crops into euphoric experiences.

In essence, Stardew Valley transcends the typical farming RPG; it stands as a sensational masterpiece that has enchanted me across various gaming platforms. With its enchanting visuals, addictive gameplay, and a plethora of activities, it's a must-play for genre enthusiasts. Whether you're a seasoned farming veteran or a newcomer to the scene, this game promises an immersive and gratifying gameplay experience.

Thank you for giving me something to connect with that I never thought was possible.

Don't know how I haven't written a review yet; I binged this game to Year 6 in high school and I'm on another run half a decade later that's souped with fun mods and messing around in the game like I've never done before. There's a wild amount you can do in this game whether it's combat, fishing mini games, romancing characters, or - like the label implies - farming. Every day is spent busy trying out new things and exploring all the fun events and quests.

I would say the romances aren't like super amazing or anything; all of the characters have simple personalities generally but I think it's easy to find favorites and want to shower them with gifts. It's easy to be like "Ooo, it's X!"

I've played a lot solo and also with friends once multiplayer comes out. Solo is still great but if you can play with friends (and even worse, wrestle with each other over a shared wallet) I highly recommend this game! Being able to play on different kinds of farms, adding dumb "I wanna woo Jodie" and "give everyone big tits!" mods, divying up tasks to everyone and finding out everyone's wasted their time playing the one arcade machine is a really fun time.

Huge replayability, starting new save files is encouraged and has huge bonuses, a good game to play with the gang, good for wasting time and trying lots of new stuff solo

I recommend Stardew Valley to anyone, and if you feel like it isn't your thing? I promise you there's a mod for that. You can completely change how the game looks, because of how dedicated and passionate the modding community is. There are also tons of quality of life mods, but the game is just fine without them, too. Give it a chance, if you haven't already!

With the free major content updates, the game cements itself as one of the most cost effective experiences ever.

Stardew Valley is one of the best games I have played in my 25+ years of playing computer games. It scratches the itch of making beautiful places, ordering chaos, building awesome stuff, resource management, adversity on your own terms (i.e. you can go seek thrills and things that might kill you....or not, up to you!), achievements, and probably one of the best sound tracks in all of gaming, at least in the top 10. The love Concerned Ape put into this game is palpable in everything you touch. The modding community is brilliant. The community, in general, are usually some of the nicest and most supportive gamers ever. After over 300hrs in this game - I cannot wait to put in another 300.

This game is awesome. There's so much you can do. I've put a lot of hours into this game and I still haven't done everything. The only thing that is slightly annoying to some other people I've recommended this game to is that the day cycle is pretty short and it takes like a quarter of a day to get from one place to another. This can get annoying because you pass out at 2:00am if you don't go back to bed, and some people just like to keep playing without having to keep going back to bed. It doesn't really bother me, but if you're not into that, then I would say this game isn't for you. Otherwise, I highly recommend it!

Similar to my appreciation for Harvest Moon, I developed a fondness for Stardew Valley upon my initial engagement with the game. While the gameplay may be characterized by simplicity and occasional repetitiveness, I derive a sense of tranquility from engaging in routine activities, complemented by the immersive ambiance and nostalgic musical backdrop. I would unequivocally assign it a rating of 10/10 and extend a wholehearted recommendation.

Eu sou um pai de 45 anos, provavelmente uma das pessoas mais velhas a jogar este jogo. Sou pai solteiro criando meu filho, que agora tem 14 anos. Meu filho ganhou este jogo de seu tio, então o instalamos em seu computador e ele começou a jogar.
Até o final da semana ele tinha 24 horas neste jogo. Isso foi horrível para mim, pois já era difícil encontrar maneiras de passar o tempo com meu filho, pois ele está sempre com os amigos ou apenas assistindo ao YouTube. Então eu decidi fazer uma conta no Steam e pegar esse jogo para ver se eu poderia jogar ao lado dele. Pedi ajuda ao meu filho e ele organizou um jogo para eu participar. 
Adorei, pois foi o melhor momento que passei com meu filho desde que minha esposa morreu. Desde então, esse jogo aproximou eu e meu filho novamente e agora passamos um tempo juntos fora de casa também. Este jogo me lembrou que há diversão em tudo, e trouxe muitas lembranças felizes para mim e meu filho.

They will never run out of quests because the NPCs has so much demands (small quests) that you can accomplish that can earn friendship points. Love the multiplayer mode too so people can play it with their friends. Can i also just say that the four-corner farm layout is so underrated?? saves me more time on dividing my farm to parts tbh. 

I recommend this game to anyone if you wanna chill like i do!

I first bought this game on my phone about 6 years ago. I remember begging my parents for the $10 or so that it was at the time because it looked that interesting to me. I know, 6 years later, own it on three different platforms (mobile, switch, pc), and do not regret a single purchase. This game is wonderful, and I recommend it to anyone interested in a very sweet game. While the combat system can be frustrating at times (even i'll admit that), everything else blows that out of the water. The farming is fun, the ranching is fun, getting to know each of the villagers is a journey that I enjoy taking. The only two systems in this game that I find flawed are fishing and combat, but with some time and practice, it becomes much easier. There is so much content in this game, and the creator is such a wonderful human being that I can't help but want to support. Even the community is great. If you're on the fence, I totally recommend this game. It has made me smile and feel joy so many times, and has truly made me loose track of time in real life from how engaged I can get in it.

Also, you can give your horse a hat. A+

This game is the thing I obsessively play when homework and/or work and life gets too much, when I just need to spend time in a fictional world that doesn't require fighting or stat blocks. This is a really great and time consuming game. With a lot of things to do. 
You can farm, expand your farm, go fishing, explore (and explode) mines, kill monsters, help villagers and many many many other things to do.
And what is the best thing in this game? You can do everything in you own pace!
+ PROS + 
+ Smooth game
+ Lovely graphics
++ Designer ++
+ Good story
+ Good characters 
+ Good soundtrack

- CONS - 
- Few times loading save file took time (usually it is really quick)
- When fishing and it should be 1/3 chances to get a specific fish from that pond, on a rainy day and in those hours and you get everything else.... so randomness is a kind of blessing and a curse at the same time. :D

But this game is awesome!
And after finishing the first play through I will  play this entertaining game again.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

●●●●●

Stardew Valley stands as a gaming masterpiece, earning a perfect score for its rich and immersive gameplay. The farming mechanics, a core element, allow players to cultivate diverse crops, tend to livestock, and explore mines, creating a holistic virtual experience. Diverse activities, from fishing to engaging in quests and relationships with in-game characters, add layers of depth, making each day in Stardew Valley meaningful and rewarding.

The game's inclusive approach to farming sets it apart. Players can tailor their experience, whether focusing on agriculture, mining, or building community relationships. This adaptability adds a personal touch, reflecting the uniqueness of each player's choices.

The game's timeless appeal and replay value complete its perfect score. Simplicity coupled with profound mechanics offers a relaxing yet engaging escape. The soothing soundtrack enhances the calming atmosphere, making Stardew Valley a game to return to for comfort and joy. Multiple farm layouts and character routes contribute to significant replay value, ensuring each playthrough feels fresh and rewarding. Stardew Valley isn't just a game; it's a captivating masterpiece with enduring charm.

Stardew Valley: A Digital Escape that Cost Me My Reality

Rating: 5/5

Stardew Valley, the beloved farming simulation game, is often praised for its charming pixel art, relaxing gameplay, and the promise of a peaceful escape from the daily grind. However, my experience with this seemingly innocent game took a dark turn, leaving me divorced and questioning the impact of my digital pursuits on my real-life relationships.

At first glance, Stardew Valley appears harmless, with its vibrant colors and simple farming mechanics. The initial allure of tending to crops, raising animals, and building relationships with virtual characters seemed like an ideal way to unwind. Little did I realize that my obsession with the game would slowly but surely erode the foundations of my marriage.

The game's addictive nature led me to spend countless hours in its virtual world, neglecting my responsibilities and, more importantly, the needs of my spouse. As my virtual farm flourished, my real-life relationship withered. Quality time together was replaced by solitary sessions on my computer, and conversations were drowned out by the soothing sounds of Stardew Valley's soundtrack.

The game's immersive social aspect, where players can form relationships with in-game characters, became a twisted parallel to reality. As my virtual connections deepened, my emotional investment in my marriage dwindled. Stardew Valley's charming townsfolk became more appealing than my own spouse, leading to a growing sense of detachment.

Ultimately, my addiction to Stardew Valley played a significant role in the breakdown of my marriage. The pixelated escape I sought turned into a heartbreaking reality check. The game's seemingly harmless façade hid the potential for real-life consequences, and I found myself divorced, grappling with the consequences of my misplaced priorities.

While Stardew Valley offers a delightful escape for many, my cautionary tale serves as a reminder that moderation is key. The digital realm should never take precedence over genuine human connections, and it's crucial to strike a balance between the virtual and the real. In my case, Stardew Valley became a cautionary tale of how a seemingly innocent game can have profound effects on one's life when taken to extremes.

This game is totally my kind of game! To be honest, I'm new to the world of pc games, but this game has already made me addicted and I can't stop playing it!

Some of the interesting things I like about this game are,

First, the story and background of each npc. We are really brought into the story of this game and become one with the villagers. Each npc has a different character so it's very interesting to follow them :D.

Secondly, we are completely given the space to customize the farm the way we want and that's really a fun thing for me. Of course we are also given the freedom to have a family with whom and even have children! Absolutely adorable ><.

Thirdly, the challenges and mysteries of the game itself make me even more curious and I can't help but improve. Honestly, I don't really like mining in this game (because I'm weak in combat T_T), but the achievements and targets in this game make me have to do it. But often I find mining and combat quite exciting as I can find items that are useful for my farm.

There are actually many other things I like about this game that I can't mention one by one. The point is, it's one of the best games I've ever played and I'm really happy I picked it up!

[h2] Achievements: [/h2]
Stardew Valley’s achievement system adds an extra layer of enjoyment. Whether you’re a completionist aiming for that coveted 100% or a casual player, there’s something for everyone. From earning your first gold coin to mastering every recipe, each achievement feels rewarding. Plus, those unique hats you unlock? They’re like little badges of honor.

[h2] Playthrough: [/h2]
Your playthrough in Stardew Valley is akin to a blank canvas waiting for your artistic touch. Will you focus on farming, mining, fishing, or building relationships? The game encourages experimentation and allows you to set your own pace. Whether you’re tending to crops, exploring the mines, or attending festivals, each day feels purposeful. And don’t forget those heartwarming events with the townspeople—they’re the heart of the game.

[h2] Game Style: [/h2]
Stardew Valley seamlessly blends nostalgia with modern gameplay. The pixel art, soothing soundtrack, and charming NPCs evoke a sense of simpler times. Yet, beneath its quaint appearance lies depth. The seasons change, crops grow, and secrets unfold. The balance between routine and surprise keeps you hooked. It’s like sipping hot cocoa by the fireplace—comforting and magical.

[h2] Overall Recommendation: [/h2]
In a world where life can be chaotic, Stardew Valley offers solace. It’s a cozy escape—a place where you can plant parsnips, raise chickens, and dance in the rain. Whether you’re a seasoned farmer or a newbie, this game welcomes you with open arms. So grab your hoe, befriend a wizard, and embrace the simple joys of tilling soil. Stardew Valley is more than a game; it’s a warm hug from a pixelated world.

I really, really, REALLY wanted to like this game.

It's made with so much love, so much passion, and it was all done by one guy. It's an incredible accomplishment and clearly a huge success. It is a genre-changer. I have tried to play it on multiple platforms, with mods and without mods, but it all just falls flat. I drop it every single time I try to play it. I simply cannot play it nor can I enjoy it.

I love Harvest Moon, I love Rune Factory, so why don't I like this game? I feel like there's something wrong with me but I just can't stand it for reasons I can't describe. Is it the graphics? Is it the music? Is it the characters? Am I just so horribly jaded that my dopamine receptors aren't working anymore? I don't know...

The closest I can come to articulating it is that the farm progression and building feels like... Factorio? One of those base building simulators where the goal is to automate everything and perfect everything and organize everything just so? It just comes off as impersonal to me, I suppose, for reasons I can't quite explain.

There's no logical reason why I dislike this game. I just do. At this point, I'm sick of it being recommended me. It's a good game. It might even be a great game. I just can't look at it anymore and twist myself into knots trying to justify why I dislike it. I'd even go so far as to say that I hate it.

99% of people will probably like this game. I'm that weird 1%, we who lurk in the dark corners and lurk in desolate alleyways. Ours is a cursed life, a half-life. We drift through time, lost to our misery. Alas, we are but cobwebs in a storm.

Stardew Valley is simultaneously the chillest game and the most intense. You can casually work your way through the life of a farmer at the most leisurely pace or you can take a hardcore dive into the deep end of capitalism.

The depth of content that this game has to offer is insanely deep and is more than enough to keep you occupied for hundreds of hours and multiple playthroughs.

So, whether you're referencing the Wiki to min-max your profits, romancing half the town to experience all the character stories or just relaxing in Pelican Town while you watch tv on your second screen; You're guaranteed a good time. Cause at the end of the day, the only wrong way to play Stardew Valley is to not play at all.

The Greatness of Stardew Valley is the fact that no matter what you want to do, or why you want to do it, you can. Don't play how others want you to play, play how you want to play. Whether that may be by making as much profit as possible, or becoming friends with everyone you can, or simply doing what feels fun at the time, you are not playing "wrong". Make a honey farm! Build a chicken utopia! Sacrifice your kids! Complete the community center or Joja Mart! anything you may want to do is never the incorrect thing to do (unless you're throwing rocks at Linus's tent, in which case I will make sure you forget how to taste :3). The only main issue currently with the game is the multiplayer aspect. it's really fun to play with your friends, but Disconnects happen all too often. overall, The game is worth the money, as long as you can deal with disconnecting from multiplayer games every once in a while.

Wanted to give this a try since there is a lot of positive buzz around this game. Played enough hours and there is no coziness, at least for me. Everything feels so restricted (time, exhaustion, number of gifts per day/week, short time quests, opening hours of shops and by that a lot of time option to talk to townies and finish those short time quests). Better description than farm simulator is time management game, which I find more stressful than relaxing. Unfortunately not what I was expecting. But I will take this as lesson to research more about these types of games, if the game play would suit me better.
